pr_title: Introduce concept of Boundary for DanglingLine and TieLine

timeline.message:
Implementation in memory for new API

Signed-off-by: RALAMBOTIANA MIORA <miora.ralambotiana@rte-france.com>

Update serialization

Signed-off-by: RALAMBOTIANA MIORA <miora.ralambotiana@rte-france.com>

Add a warning if tieline values are ignored during XML import

Signed-off-by: RALAMBOTIANA MIORA <miora.ralambotiana@rte-france.com>

Add tests

Signed-off-by: RALAMBOTIANA MIORA <miora.ralambotiana@rte-france.com>

Add tests

Signed-off-by: RALAMBOTIANA MIORA <miora.ralambotiana@rte-france.com>

timeline.bodyText: I am not sure to like BoundaryPoint name choice indeed. We have no Point in IIDM: we have node, bus and terminal. When you do getBoundaryPoint(Branch.Side.ONE).getP() for me you refer to a terminal and it will be clearer to do getHalf1().getBoundaryTerminal().getP().
timeline.author: annetill
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -639,9 +639,9 @@ private void writeLines(AmplExportContext context, TableFormatter formatter) thr
                         .writeCell(-1) // no ratio tap changer
                         .writeCell(-1) // no phase tap changer
                         .writeCell(t1.getP())
-                        .writeCell(-tl.getHalf1().getXnodeP()) // xnode node flow side 1
+                        .writeCell(-tl.getBoundaryPoint(Branch.Side.ONE).getP()) // xnode node flow side 1

replies.bodyText: I don't like using the term Terminal when it is not really a Terminal object... It is a bit confusing, for me it is not a node, bus or terminal and this is why I created another term.
replies.author: miovd

replies.bodyText: Maybe we can remove the point word and keep getBoundary(Side)? But I agree with @MioRtia, terminal would be confusing for IIDM-fluent people as there is no Terminal object there
replies.author: mathbagu

replies.bodyText:
Another proposal:
tieLine.getHalf1().getOtherSide().getP()
danglingLine.getOtherSide().getP()
In that proposal for tie lines, the half line is not hidden because it is comparable to dangling line concept.
About the sign: I think that Mathieu is right, the sign should not changed as P at t1 has the opposite sign of P at boundary terminal. Indeed a test is missing in the AMPL converter.
replies.author: annetill

timeline.message:
Rename boundary point values of tieline in XIIDM 1.5

Signed-off-by: RALAMBOTIANA MIORA <miora.ralambotiana@rte-france.com>

Rename boundary point values of tieline in XIIDM 1.5

Signed-off-by: RALAMBOTIANA MIORA <miora.ralambotiana@rte-france.com>

timeline.bodyText: I wonder if the sign are OK (same question above): could you confirm it is?
timeline.author: mathbagu
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -665,9 +665,9 @@ private void writeLines(AmplExportContext context, TableFormatter formatter) thr
                         .writeCell(1f) // constant ratio
                         .writeCell(-1) // no ratio tap changer
                         .writeCell(-1) // no phase tap changer
-                        .writeCell(-tl.getHalf2().getXnodeP()) // xnode node flow side 2
+                        .writeCell(-tl.getBoundaryPoint(Branch.Side.TWO).getP()) // xnode node flow side 2
                         .writeCell(t2.getP())
-                        .writeCell(-tl.getHalf2().getXnodeQ()) // xnode node flow side 2
+                        .writeCell(-tl.getBoundaryPoint(Branch.Side.TWO).getQ()) // xnode node flow side 2

replies.bodyText: Not sure but xnodeQ and otherSide.getQ() were the same sign but I will check
replies.author: miovd

timeline.author: mathbagu
mathbagu

replies.bodyText: I don't know, it would throw a null pointer exception (as every time we call it, it is to have a value and this object is supposed to never be null), wouldn't it be weird and more difficult to debug?
replies.author: miovd

timeline.author: mathbagu
mathbagu

timeline.bodyText: If values are computed, why do we read/write them? For instance we do not serialize the intensity (Terminal.getI())
timeline.author: mathbagu

replies.bodyText: Good question, I don't remember why we wanted to serialize it... maybe it is not useful as you said. What do you think @annetill ?
replies.author: miovd

replies.bodyText: After thinking and @zamarrenolm 's input, I think you are right
replies.author: miovd

timeline.bodyText: Same question: I would only write xnodeP and xnodeQ to keep compatibilty with old XIIDM version
timeline.author: mathbagu

timeline.bodyText: Why don't use the same type for DanglingLine and TieLines and serialize them as a sub-element?
timeline.author: mathbagu
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -540,8 +547,10 @@
                 <xs:attribute name="g2_1" use="required" type="xs:double"/>
                 <xs:attribute name="b1_1" use="required" type="xs:double"/>
                 <xs:attribute name="b2_1" use="required" type="xs:double"/>
-                <xs:attribute name="xnodeP_1" use="required" type="xs:double"/>
-                <xs:attribute name="xnodeQ_1" use="required" type="xs:double"/>
+                <xs:attribute name="boundaryPointP_1" use="optional" type="xs:double"/>
+                <xs:attribute name="boundaryPointQ_1" use="optional" type="xs:double"/>
+                <xs:attribute name="boundaryPointV_1" use="optional" type="xs:double"/>
+                <xs:attribute name="boundaryPointAngle_1" use="optional" type="xs:double"/>
